greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Array read by antidiagonals: T(m,n) = number of dominating sets in the lattice (rook) graph K_m X K_n.
comment: A set of vertices can be represented as a m X n binary matrix. If all rows contain at least one 1 then regardless of what is in each row the set will form a dominating set giving (2^n-1)^m solutions. Otherwise if only i<m rows contain at least one 1 then all columns must contain a 1 for the set to form a dominating set giving A183109(i,n) solutions.
link: Andrew Howroyd, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..780
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Dominating Set
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Rook Graph
mathematica: a[m_, n_] := (2^n - 1)^m + Sum[ b[i, n]*Binomial[m, i], {i, 1, m - 1}];
Table[a[m - n + 1, n], {m, 1, 9}, {n, 1, m}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 12 2017, adapted from PARI *)
xref: Cf. A183109, A088699 (independent vertex sets), A290632.
results.author: _Andrew Howroyd_, May 22 2017
